info.game_comments:
Sam Ott game 1.
Last game of Season 19.

(1, 1).clue: In trucking a triple-sized one of these, pulled by a tractor, can be as long as a 10-story building

(2, 1).clue: In 2002 Mr. Potato Head was the guest of honor at the annual Spud Day celebration in Shelley in this state

(3, 1).clue: When Lake Bonneville evaporated thousands of years ago, it left tons of this on the flats

(4, 1).clue: On the back of the current U.S. bill fronted by this man, you can see a statue of him

(5, 1).clue: 1973 brought the first Bond theme performed by a rock group: this title track heard here
(5, 1).correct response: "Live and Let Die" (by Paul McCartney & Wings)

(6, 1).clue: A simpler way of saying "more lobster-colored"

(1, 2).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew reports from the Goodyear blimp facility.)  2 major types of airships are non-rigid, or blimps, & rigid, also called by this name of a German count

(2, 2).clue: In June at a Tuscumbia, Alabama festival honoring her, "The Miracle Worker" is performed at her birthplace

(3, 2).clue: Lake Mead straddles the border between these 2 states

(4, 2).clue: He's the only man on a current U.S. bill who petitioned for an officer's commission in the British military

(5, 2).clue: Nobody does it better than this woman who sang "Nobody Does It Better"

(1, 3).clue: In the 1940s Robert Edison Fulton Jr. designed the Airphibian, a car that was also one of these

(2, 3).clue: The Jewish festival of Shavuot commemorates the revelation of the Torah at this site

(3, 3).clue: The community college in Canandaigua, New York is named for this "handy" group of bodies of water

(4, 3).clue: Inflation?  In 1907 he was on the 5-dollar bill; today he's worth 4 times that

(5, 3).clue: This 1965 song heard here almost didn't get used in favor of one called "Mr. Kiss Kiss Bang Bang"

(6, 3).clue: A noise made by a chick, or to look quickly or secretly

(1, 4).clue: Offered since 1959, it gives you travel for a fixed time period on train systems in 17 European countries

(2, 4).clue: During WWI, WWII & the Energy Crisis of 1974-75, the U.S. adopted this for most of the year to economize on fuel

(3, 4).clue: Fed by lakes Victoria & Edward, it's also known as Lake Mobutu Sese Seko

(5, 4).clue: It took 20 years & Duran Duran to take a Bond tune to No. 1 -- this 1985 hit

(1, 5).clue: Scheduled to set sail in 2004, its logo is seen here(QM2)

(2, 5).clue: This N.M. national park has a Bat Flight Breakfast in August so that visitors can view bats returning to their caves

(3, 5).clue: The axolotl is a salamander found in Lake Xochimilco near this world capital

(5, 5).clue: This singer heard here was the first to perform onscreen during a Bond title sequence

(6, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew walks out from behind a helicopter)  It's the name for the hard-working part of a helicopter that provides upward lift & forward thrust

(1, 1).clue: The son of a Protestant clergyman, Carl Jung was born in this mountainous country in 1875

(2, 1).clue: "And the angel of the Lord appeared unto" this man "in a flame of fire out of the midst of a bush"

(3, 1).clue: It's believed that sugar buildup in tree leaves forms anthocyanins, causing this to happen

(4, 1).clue: Judge Charles Older was a character in 1976's "Helter Skelter", but this Charles was a bigger role

(5, 1).clue: In ads it was "2 all-beef patties...lettuce, cheese, pickles, onions on a sesame seed bun" -- & that special sauce

(6, 1).clue: In 1782 it became a national symbol

(1, 2).clue: Jung called these "unidentified" things, first reported by pilot Kenneth Arnold in 1947, "a modern myth"

(2, 2).clue: The damage caused by a fire in 976 to this famous Venice cathedral took about 100 years to restore

(4, 2).clue: "Quiz Show" features Paul Scofield as Mark Van Doren & this actor as his son Charles

(5, 2).clue: Tomatoes, beets, celery, carrots, lettuce, parsley, watercress & spinach are the octet in this brand

(1, 3).clue: Seeing the view as too reductionist, Jung believed Sigmund Freud overemphasized the importance of this drive

(2, 3).clue: The party's definitely over when this legendary hall is destroyed by fire at the end of "Gotterdammerung"

(4, 3).clue: In a Noel Coward play, Charles Condomine hosts a seance at his house & this title entity materializes

(5, 3).clue: It "smelled like turpentine and looked like India ink.  I held my nose, I closed my eyes, I took a drink"

(6, 3).clue: An 1867 Mussorgsky symphonic composition is about a "Night on" this

(1, 4).clue: Jung practiced this "free" technique for exploring the mind in which a patient responds to stimulus words

(2, 4).clue: Because it burns in air with a hot & brilliant flame, this gas, C2H2, is used for welding & cutting metal

(4, 4).clue: In the '80s, he played Charles Ryder, a central character in TV's "Brideshead Revisited"

(5, 4).clue: This soda, the oldest major soft drink brand in the U.S., contains a mixture of fruit juices (but prune isn't one of them)

(6, 4).clue: In French this Absurdist play from Eugene Ionesco is "La Cantatrice Chauve"

(1, 5).clue: According to Jung, the collective unconscious of man is made up of these primordial symbols

(2, 5).clue: In Dickens' "Great Expectations", this character dies when her faded wedding dress catches fire

(4, 5).clue: 3-named actor who played 3-named TV surgeon Charles Emerson Winchester

(5, 5).clue: This steak sauce was created for King George IV of England

(6, 5).clue: "Saving Faith" & "Absolute Power" are among the bestselling novels by this author

(0, 0).clue: Her first name comes from an Italian musical term meaning to play "with sweetness"
